audio_description: Assalamu Alaikum! In today’s meal, I am your host Taood, and today’s dish is the queen of all biryanis — Bombay Biryani! And we’re going to make it in an authentic way, just like the restaurant-style or wedding-style Bombay Biryani. Before we begin, I request you to please subscribe to the channel, like, share, and press the bell icon. Come along with me, let’s get started quickly.

audio_description: Bismillah-ir-Rahman-ir-Rahim. Let's begin by reciting Durood Sharif. For our Bombay Biryani, which we are making with mutton, we are taking 1 kg of mutton and adding two tomatoes. This will create a great marinade for the Bombay Biryani. I’ve chopped about 8–10 green chilies here.

audio_description: Whole spices include 1 tablespoon cumin, along with black cardamom, cinnamon, cloves, and bay leaf. Use as needed, but generously, because the packaged garam masala doesn’t have strong flavor. I’ve browned 3 onions here. I’m adding one and a half onions to the marinade and saving the rest for layering later.

audio_description: Now I’m adding ½ kg yogurt. The better the yogurt, the better the marinade. The more flavorful the masalas you add to the biryani, the better the outcome. Add 1 tbsp crushed red chili, 1½ tbsp ground red chili, 1 tbsp coriander powder, and 1 tsp turmeric.

audio_description: 1 tablespoon garam masala powder, 1 teaspoon nutmeg and mace powder. We’ll also add some dried plums. Mix the marinade well. This is the same oil in which I fried the onions. It’s very easy — some people cook the meat raw in Bombay, while others marinate it like this. But this method gives a very tasty and aromatic result — people are crazy about Bombay Biryani.

audio_description: Marination is done.

Even after cooking, you can adjust the salt level. The Bombay Biryani should be slightly salty so that when you add the rice — since here the masala is kept separate unlike other biryanis — it balances well. I’ll also show you how I separate the masala. Our marination is now complete.
